message_1:
Solve the following inequality and graph its solution on a number line: 

3x + 4 > 10 

Note: The inequality can be solved by subtracting 4 from both sides and then dividing by 3.
message_2:
To solve the inequality 3x + 4 > 10, we will follow the steps you mentioned.

Step 1: Subtract 4 from both sides.
3x + 4 - 4 > 10 - 4
3x > 6

Step 2: Divide by 3.
3x/3 > 6/3
x > 2

The solution to the inequality is x > 2. Now, we will graph this solution on a number line.

1. Draw a number line with an arrow on the right side, indicating that the line extends infinitely in the positive direction.
2. Place a point at 2 on the number line.
3. Since x > 2, we will draw an open circle at 2 (indicating that 2 is not included in the solution) and shade the region to the right of 2 (indicating that all numbers greater than 2 are part of the solution).

The graph of the solution on the number line will look like this:

------(2)----->
